title: Donald Trump's tough guy letter to Erdogan is mocked
text:
Donald Trump's letter to Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has been mocked for its simplistic tones, with the White House even challenged by members of the press pack who asked if the note was 'actually real'.

In the letter, which was written on October 9 as Erdogan's forces prepared to cross into Syria, Trump urges Turkey's hardman president to 'not be a fool' as he warns the leader against the invasion.

But the 'adolescent quality' of the note did little to impress former presidential adviser David Gergen, who told CNN he assumed the letter was a fake, the Huffington Post reported.

'When I read it, I immediately called my research assistant and said, 'See if this is fake. I just can't believe the White House sent this out'', he said.

Donald Trump's letter to Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has been mocked for its simplistic tones

'It is unprecedented to the best of my knowledge, and I do think it makes it tougher to work with Turkey, which is a member of NATO, and we need to figure out a way to get this stopped short of much more violence.'

'Let's work out a good deal!' Trump wrote in the letter. 'You don't want to be responsible for slaughtering thousands of people, and I don't want to be responsible for destroying the Turkish economy—and I will.

'History will look upon you favorably if you get this done the right and humane way. It will look upon you forever as the devil if good things don't happen.

'Don't be a tough guy. Don't be a fool!' he added. 'I will call you later.'

The letter was leaked to Trish Reagan, an evening anchor on the Fox Business Network, with many Twitter users, including White House correspondents, initially believing it to be a hoax.

In the letter, which was written on October 9 as Erdogan's forces prepared to cross into Syria, Trump urges Turkey's hardman president to 'not be a fool'

Several journalists took to the social network on Wednesday to confirm the note was, in fact, legitimate after they were forced to seek confirmation from the White House that the 'embarrassing' letter was real.

Katie Rogers, White House correspondent for the New York Times, said: 'Felt the need to ask WH if this is actually real and it is.'

Washington Post columnist Brian Klaas added: 'Honestly this letter from Trump to Erdogan would make more sense if it were written in crayon on lined practice paper rather than on White House letterhead'.

International affairs academic Tom Nichols also took to the social network to brand the letter 'embarrassing beyond words'.

The letter was leaked to Trish Reagan, an evening anchor on the Fox Business Network, with many Twitter users initially believing it to be a hoax

He said: 'This is embarrassing beyond words. It suggests the President is mentally unstable. No competent staff would have let this thing leave the building.

'Imagine the letters we haven't seen'.

Wajahat Ali added: 'The best/worst part is Trump probably leaked his Erdogan letter to Fox News thinking it made him look strong and smart'.

Reports said the letter was passed around at a meeting with congressional leaders on Wednesday, with copies also handed out on the Senate floor.

The note was not received well by the Turkish president, it was revealed today, who was said to have thrown it in the bin when he received it.

Turkish officials told the BBC that the letter was 'thoroughly rejected' by Erdogan, who promptly placed it in the bin and considered it 'the final straw'.

Mark Lowen, the BBC's Turkey correspondent tweeted today: 'When President Erdogan received Trump's letter, he 'thoroughly rejected it, threw it in the bin' and launched the Syria operation the same day. His mind was already made up to move in; letter was reportedly the final straw.'

The note was also not received well by the Turkish president, who was said to have thrown it in the bin when he received it

These reports have thrown into question hopes that Mike Pence will be able to convince Turkey to halt its offensive against Kurdish fighters in northeast Syria when he meets with Erdogan today amid a deepening humanitarian crisis.

Trump said on Wednesday that he hadn't given Erdogan 'a green light' to invade Syria. He also claimed releasing 'a very powerful letter' would dispel misconceptions about the impact of his troop withdrawal days before he wrote the note.

'If anybody saw the letter, which can be released very easily if you'd like – I could certainly release it,' he said.

'But I wrote a letter right after that conversation – a very powerful letter. There was never given a green light.'
